content:
EXISTING STRUCTURES
──────────────────────
### Copper Cable Factory Interface at Position(x=2.5, y=17.5)
Consists of the production‐side interface for copper cable assembly:
– Burner Inserter at Position(x=2.5, y=16.5)
– Cable Factory Input Chest at Position(x=2.5, y=17.5)
– Dedicated Burner Inserter placed with direction RIGHT at Position(x=3.5, y=17.5)
– Assembling Machine at Position(x=1.5, y=19.5) (as identified among neighbour entities)

### Extraction System at Position(x=-3.5, y=27.5)
Consists of the extraction component used for transferring copper plates:
– Extraction System Burner Inserter at Position(x=-3.5, y=27.5) with drop position Position(x=-3.5, y=28.5)

### Belt Depot for Extraction System Output at Position(x=3.5, y=15.5)
Consists of the intermediary belt depot for receiving extracted items:
– Wooden Chest serving as belt depot at Position(x=3.5, y=15.5)
– Dedicated Transport Belt Segment placed adjacent at Position(x=4.5, y=15.5)
– Depot Burner Inserter placed with direction UP at Position(x=3.5, y=14.5) 
  • Pickup position: Position(x=3.5, y=15.5)
  • Drop position: Position(x=3.5, y=13.5)

ERROR TIPS
────────────
– When connecting transport belts, the target must not be a steam engine. Always ensure an inserter is in place to feed items into the target entity rather than connecting the belt directly to a Prototype.SteamEngine.
– When placing entities such as wooden chests, verify that the player is within the allowable placement range. (A reported error indicated a target position was too far from the player.)
– Prior to placement, confirm that the required item is present in the inventory to avoid placement failures due to insufficient resources.
– Check that variable names are correctly defined and referenced. An undefined variable (e.g. “target_chest”) error suggests a need for consistent and precise naming in the command logic.
